description: Perhaps related to Norwegian skragg (a lean person), dialectal Swedish skragge (old and torn thing), Danish skrog (hull, carcass); perhaps related to shrink.

entries.meaning: (archaic) A thin or scrawny person or animal. [from the 16th c.]
examples: In any event he might have wakened the long scrag by so doing.

entries.meaning: (archaic) The lean end of a neck of mutton; the scrag end.
(archaic) The neck, especially of a sheep.
(UK, slang, derogatory) A chav or ned; a stereotypically loud and aggressive person of lower social class.
(Australia, slang, derogatory) A rough or unkempt woman.
A ragged, stunted tree or branch.

verbs.description: scrag (third-person singular simple present scrags, present participle scragging, simple past and past participle scragged)

entries.meaning: (obsolete, colloquial) To hang on a gallows, or to choke, garotte, or strangle.

examples: '...I urged him ... to ... try the Ickenham System ... a little thing I knocked together in my bachelor days ... it has a good many points in common with all-in wrestling and osteopathy. I generally recommend it to diffident wooers and it always works like magic...'
'You mean you told McMurdo to … scrag her?'
